text:
> *Jonjonjon*  [12:59 AM]
> Suppose I have an unmatched bet for £2. If I update it’s size to £3, will this go to the back of the queue? Or will its queue position be the original £2, plus the additional £1 at the back of the queue?
So are the orders matched fifo or is it matched with everyone in proportion to the overall size?

elements.text: Jonjonjon

[12:59 AM]
Suppose I have an unmatched bet for £2. If I update it’s size to £3, will this go to the back of the queue? Or will its queue position be the original £2, plus the additional £1 at the back of the queue?
So are the orders matched fifo or is it matched with everyone in proportion to the overall size?

text: I think order matching on betfair is more complicated than the regular fifo, that's why a lot of ladder trading softwares don't even bother showing the position in queue (PIQ) for your orders, and the ones that show are not always accurate

elements.text: I think order matching on betfair is more complicated than the regular fifo, that's why a lot of ladder trading softwares don't even bother showing the position in queue (PIQ) for your orders, and the ones that show are not always accurate

text: ~size of the order has implications on the matching I believe~, ~if there's an opposite order with the same size than you might get matched ahead of the queue and stuff like that.~ I don't even think the order matching algorithm is fully disclosed (might be wrong here, correct me please)

elements.text: size of the order has implications on the matching I believe
if there's an opposite order with the same size than you might get matched ahead of the queue and stuff like that.
I don't even think the order matching algorithm is fully disclosed (might be wrong here, correct me please)

text: On paper it’s fifo but cross matching makes it complicated, order size does *not* impact your position

elements.text: On paper it’s fifo but cross matching makes it complicated, order size does
not
impact your position

text: Thanks for correcting, I was under the impression that a perfect opposite order would make it quicker.

elements.text: Thanks for correcting, I was under the impression that a perfect opposite order would make it quicker.

text: The intention is FIFO but it’s not guaranteed

elements.text: The intention is FIFO but it’s not guaranteed

text: I can't remember if the matching engine is discussed in this talk per se but some interesting technical details here: <https://ppb.technology/2019/09/24/showcasing-betfair-exchange-at-kafka-summit-london/>

attachments.title: Showcasing the Betfair Exchange at Kafka Summit, London
attachments.text:
A few months ago, I had a unique opportunity to represent Betfair at the prestigious Kafka Summit in London where I presented the story behind how the Betfair Exchange evolved technologically from a monolithic system with serious reliability problems that was tightly coupled to an RDBMS, to a modern, event-driven, scalable and reliable platform, that is the backbone of our global business today. The talk mainly focused on how Kafka has played and continues to play a central role in this transformation. It was a fifty minute talk at the end of a long day of presentations and I was the only one standing between the audience and a cocktail party at the time. However, I was both surprised and proud of the turnout at this session, which I was told was the largest the Use cases stream of talks, for the entire day and I thoroughly enjoyed presenting our work to the packed audience. Given the time, the presentation had a deliberately casual tone,  but the technical crux of the presentation was not lost on anyone. After the presentation I had the opportunity to interact with architects and senior developers from various organisations across the globe, who were interested in delving deeper into the technical nitty-gritties of our system and in discussing how they could solve their own problems, using some of the patterns we have used at Betfair.
Here is a brief abstract of the presentation, Confluent hosted video recording, standalone video and the slides from the presentation.
Kafka Summit is the premier event for data architects, engineers, devops professionals, and developers who want to learn about streaming data. It brings the Apache Kafka community together to share best practices, write code, and discuss the future of streaming technologies. I was really privileged to represent Betfair here and showcase what is a truly world class distributed system implementation built around Kafka, more importantly presenting the outcome of painstaking and diligent hard work of the entire Exchange Platform development team, here in London, over a number of years.
If you like to be part of this journey as we continue to evolve the Exchange towards an exciting future, apply here.
attachments.fallback: Paddy Power Betfair's Technology Blog Link: Showcasing the Betfair Exchange at Kafka Summit, London

text:
Thanks for looking at the PR. My change in bflw allows users to pass generators into

betfairlightweight.streaming.betfairstream.HistoricalStream .

Prior to the change, HistoricalStream expected a directory.

Looking through path of execution for the backtest.py example, if eventually gets to

flumine/streams/historicalstream.py

which creates the HistoricalGeneratorStream class (which is from betfairlightweight, and currently expects the directory, not generator.).

Is that the point at which you believe the change should be made?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text:
Thanks for looking at the PR. My change in bflw allows users to pass generators into

betfairlightweight.streaming.betfairstream.HistoricalStream .

Prior to the change, HistoricalStream expected a directory.

Looking through path of execution for the backtest.py example, if eventually gets to

flumine/streams/historicalstream.py

which creates the HistoricalGeneratorStream class (which is from betfairlightweight, and currently expects the directory, not generator.).

Is that the point at which you believe the change should be made?

text: Yep sorry I wasn’t very clear, passing a generator could probably completely remove the need for historicalstream.py in flumine as the generator could be appended to streams.Streams.streams and the just looped

text: simplifies the exchange arch on their end, less messaging. Likely why they are broadly fifo

elements.text: simplifies the exchange arch on their end, less messaging. Likely why they are broadly fifo

text: Some markets would probably be better suited to prorata or a prorata/fifo mix (think soccer where odds are pretty stable premarket and hard to get filled behind someone's fat stack)

elements.text: Some markets would probably be better suited to prorata or a prorata/fifo mix (think soccer where odds are pretty stable premarket and hard to get filled behind someone's fat stack)

text: fwiw, prorata is actually better for HFTs than fifo - I know of some teams who trade prorata markets in the financial world who in several years have never lost money on a trade in a pro-rata market

elements.text: fwiw, prorata is actually better for HFTs than fifo - I know of some teams who trade prorata markets in the financial world who in several years have never lost money on a trade in a pro-rata market
